One question that comes

Red Hat has several upstream
open source projects

parts of these migrations.

They've packaged these
up as migration toolkits
that are available to be deployed

One of these is familiar
to a lot of people

Toolkit for Containers.

you install it on OpenShift,

you connect to a source

a destination OpenShift environment,

and then actually migrate
the application workloads,

the persistent volumes,
the configurations,
from one OpenShift environment to another.

The migration toolkits are
not magical silver bullets.
They don't solve every single problem.
The goal with the migration toolkits

is to take the 80% of
things that can be migrated

with relative ease and help
customers pull those in
so that they can focus on the 20%

where there may need to be
some sort of refactoring.

There are many approaches
to migrating workloads.

The concept behind Red Hat's
open source Konveyor project

and these toolkits is,
how do we take a toolkit

and provide customers
with a guardrail mechanism

so that we can identify where
the customer's done things
that are gonna be detrimental?
Has the customer hardcoded things,
has the customer created dependencies

that they haven't
documented, aren't aware of?
How do we detect those in the toolkits

How do we compensate for those?

It's those unforeseen pitfalls
